{Sorghum vulgare.")
Part I.
FIELD OBSERVATIONS AND REPORTS. 1
BY A. T. PBTEHS.
kThe Nebraska Experiment Station has for a number of are collected reports of cases of loss of animals from eat I green sorghum.
I Special experiments to determine the cause of death from ttle running in sorghum fields were undertaken by the epartment of Animal Pathology during the summer of 01, as the result of numerous inquiries which came to the ation asking for remedies and reporting deaths of animals at had been pastured on sorghum or had broken into rghum fields. In most cases these animals did not regurly pasture upon sorghum, but broke into the fields from jacent pastures or as they were being driven past fields sorghum. Investigation proved that the animals did not b from bloat as has been reported by many agricultural pers. Many cases were reported where death occurred thout bloat and in so short a time that no other theory cept that of poison seemed tenable. In most instances iere' losses of this kind were reported, the sorghum had en stunted in its growth and was not entirely healthy and jorous in its appearance.
tWe visited many fields where animals had died, but genally found these animals in so advanced a stage of decom-
tPart of the material here presented is from the 15th Annual Report this Station.
BULL. 77, AGR. EXP. STATION OF NEBR. VOL. XV, ART. III.

* A(/l$€/rti-7lg Oj I .dlllc Oy tSOrgflmrrl iZflCZ _/\ djlr {^.(/fft*
position that satisfactory post mortems could not be held. Often the animals had been buried, and when other animals were turned into these fields they refused to eat the sorghum and no information could be secured.
In the spring of 1901, special effort was made to further the investigation of sorghum poisoning. A notice was placed in the leading State papers to the effect that the Experiment Station would send a veterinarian to investigate all cases of so-called sorghum poisoning, if notified in time to be of assistance or to secure any information. We responded to numerous calls of this kind, but in most instances where animals were turned upon the sorghum for the express purpose of poisoning them they refused to eat, and no data could be secured.
In response to one of these calls, I reached the farm of Mr. Bert Foss, near Aurora, at 7 :30 a.m., on August 3, 1901. Two days previous, fifteen head of his cattle had broken into a sorghum field, where they had remained twenty minutes. They were then driven into another field and were not seen again for several hours. When seen, three were sick, all of which died within a few hours. Th<> symptoms were drowsiness, running at the eyes, twitching of the nius cles, numbness of the limbs, staggering gait, inability to stand, involuntary passing of urine. On August 2, two MR cows broke through the fence and were on the sorghum ftdd five minutes. One hour later, one of these animals, a fouryear-old cow, was very sick, but finally recovered.
We turned a small yearling steer on the sorghum at 8:30 a.m., August 3, but he refused to eat any sorghum, and after thirty-five minutes two more were turned into the sorghum, where they remained until 10:00 a.m., when only one. ¦ small, red steer, had taken any sorghum, and he had eaten only a few leaves. They were then turned back with the herd. At 10:35 a.m. the small, red steer acted somewhat drowsy, but soon recovered.
At 11:00 a.m. we turned one red heifer and one yearling steer on the sorghum. The heifer was the only animal that ate any quantity, and, as subsequent examination showed, she ate only one and one-half pounds of green sorghum. At 11:10 a.m. this animal dropped to the ground. Upon ex-

5
amination it was found that she had stopped chewing her cud and there was a peculiar twitching of the muscles of the nose and head and also of the body. The animal was very dull. At 11 :15 a.m. she was taken out of the sorghum field and allowed to lie in a stubble field. When lying dowu her head was turned toward the abdomen, presenting the symptoms shown by a horse having the colic. The eyes seemed dull and gave off a watery discharge. There was a partial paralysis of the tongue and great quantities of saliva ran from the mouth. The limbs and ears were cold. The pupils of the eyes dilated, pulse not perceptible, mucous membrane of the rectum protruding, involuntary discharge of urine and faeces. Upon pricking the animal with a knife on the lower limbs it showed no feeling. This animal was closely watched in the field by Mr. Foss and myself and we observed that she did not take any weeds, but simply a small amount of sorghum, eating only the tops of the leaves. At 1 :30 p.m. the animal was still lying on its right side; all the muscles of the head were contracted and showed involuntary twitching. The limbs were paralyzed and the animal was unconscious; the mucous membrane of the mouth was of a salmon color. At 2 :35 p.m. the animal was in great pain, and it was apparent that she would not recover. At the suggestion of Mr. Foss the animal was killed in order to hold a post-mortem examination.
Post-Moutem Examination. — Animal still warm. The bowels were opened and contents of paunch carefully noted ; there was in all one pound and a half of sorghum leaves to be found in the paunch. No sourness of the contents. The same was immediately put up in Mason fruit jars with clean water and brought to the laboratory. The mucous membrane of the intestines normal, all other conditions of the animal normal. Made particular examination of the pharynx (throat), epiglottis, and esophagus, and found that there were no leaves lodged over the same. If this had occurred the animal would have died instantly and not within three or more hours as our record shows, and would have died in the state of asphyxia and not presenting the symptoms of acute poisoning. In eleven post mortems that we conducted, careful search has always failed to reveal any leaves ob-

6
structing the pharynx, epiglottis, or esophagus, which would have caused death by asphyxia or strangulation.
I One case of sorghum poisoning is reported from sorghum at had been cut several hours before feeding. Mr. E. F. oner, of Chester, cut sorghum at 8 K)0 o'clock p.m., August which was fed to three milch cows at 8:00 a.m., August 3. >out 9:00 o'clock a.m. these animals were first noticed to sick. One died within an hour and fifteen minutes. The lier two recovered within twelve hours. On August 6 I tited this sorghum field and made an examination of the rghum, which was not fully matured. It was comparaely free from weeds. At 5:45 p.m. we placed a cow in is sorghum field and allowed her to eat as much cut rghum as she would, up to 8:00 p.m., when she had conmed about twenty pounds. At 7 :00 a.m., on August 7, the imal showed no effects of sorghum poisoning, and no bad ects followed.
I The season of 1902 was unusually wet in most sections of e State. As a result of the vigorous growth of sorghum, iv cases of poisoning have been reported. On July 24, Mr. illiam J. Smith, of Cambridge, lost two cows as the result feeding green sorghum. On the 30th of July, Mr. H. B. ade and 1 visited the farm of Mr. Smith and made a physiojical test of the effect upon a cow of the sorghum growing the field. A full-sized Jersey cow was turned into the rghum patch shortly after 9 :00 o'clock. At 9 :10 the aniil began to eat the sorghum and kept quite steadily at it p the next few minutes. She soon ceased, became uneasy, d in ten minutes after she had taken the first mouthful of rghum she was seen to lurch suddenly as if she had lost her lance. From that time on the symptoms of poisoning pidly developed, and the cow passed into a semi-comatose ndition. After five hours the effect of the poison appeared isened and the cow recovered.
Pe fresh air acted to some extent as an antidote, and by o'clock the animal was able to rejoin the herd. Samples rghum taken from the locality where the cow had eaten examined in the laboratory and found to produce pruscid. The symptoms and the presence of prussic acid in sorghum afford unmistakable evidence of the cause of

7
the poisoning. The action upon the heart, respiration, and nervous centers as well as the incipient diarrhoea are all characteristic symptoms of prussic acid poisoning, and tho smell of the acid about the mouth was sufficient by itself to identify the poison.
The sorghum from this field gave chemical tests for prussic acid.
[While no later reports of poisoning in the State have been ceived, the Chemical Department continued the study of e occurrence in plants of compounds capable of liberating ussic acid. Prussic acid had just been obtained from ifir corn growing on the University farm when the folding letter was received :
"State Agricultural College and Experiment Station, i "Department of Veterinary Science. Geo. H. Glover. \ "Fort Collins, Colorado, September 17, 1902. ) "Director Experiment Station, IAncoln, Nebr.:
"Dear Sir — We have recently experienced a fearful loss of cattle in this State from eating Kafir corn; twenty-one head of dairy cows out of thirty-two dying within an hour after first being placed upon the feed. This corn was a stunted growth being above the ditch. Will you kindly inform me if you experienced any such difficulty in Nebraska or give any further information bearing on the subject?
"Yours respectfully,
(Signed) "Geo. H. Glover."
[As the result of the correspondence with the Department Veterinary Science of the Colorado Agricultural College, was arranged that this Station should co-operate in instigating the outbreak. Accordingly Dr. S. Avery visited e Colorado Station for this purpose. The cattle belonged Eugene F. Pitman and his mother, Mrs. Susan R. Pitman, Brighton, Colo. Mr. Pitman kindly furnished the followg information :
("The cattle died on August 20 last. We lost 21 head out 32 head which had been turned on the corn. Eleven head ed, but 4 of the 11 head had violent spasms, but recovered. te other 7 head were not affected. They were only on the rn 5 or 6 minutes. The first cow died in 15 minutes;

8
Poisoning of Cattle by Sorghum and Kafir Corn.
nearly all within an hour. One yearling lived over 6 hours. I gave it several doses of aconite, thinking possibly one poison would counteract the other, but it died in great agony. The cattle seemed to all go crazy at once, then stagger like a person intoxicated, fall in all directions, and die where they fell. I stuck all of them with a knife, the same as in alfalfa bloat, but there wasn't any gas in them. The Kafir corn was planted on sod ground above irrigation. It was from 6 to 15 inches high and was burnt brown from the
Shortly after the poisoning, Dr. Glover visited the field and collected samples, which he generously placed at our disposal. These samples yielded prussic acid in greater amounts than any yet examined in Nebraska.
More definite information in regard to the conclusions drawn from the chemical investigations, as well as observations in regard to the conditions under which sorghum becomes dangerous, will be given in Part II of this bulletin.

9
Part II.
CHEMICAL INVESTIGATIONS.'
BY S. AVERT.
The investigations of the Department of Animal Pathology have been given in Part I of this bulletin. That work furnished the basis of chemical investigation.
Some three years ago Dr. A. T. Peters arrived at the following conclusions regarding the loss of cattle from eating green sorghum :
1. Animals do not die from bloat or indigestion.
2. They do not choke to death.
The deaths result from a violent poison in sorghum of inted growth.
4. The symptoms are those of prussic acid poisoning.
tThe chemical investigations on the subject here recorded plain and confirm the conclusions drawn by the veteririan from his field work.
Definite knowledge of the poisonous principle in these plants was wanting till very recently. As late a publication as the Yearbook of the Department of Agriculture for 1900 contains the suggestion that in many cases death may result from choking. In 1886 Berthelot and Andre* ascribed the cause to excessive amounts of potassium nitrate (saltpeter). Williams 4 of the U. S. Department of Agriculture also suggests saltpeter as a cause of the trouble. Hiltner 5 has shown
'The chemical work on prussic acid in Sorghum vulgare (common sorghum and Kafir corn) was begun by Mr. Henry B. Slade and has been continued by the writer. Mr. Slade, who is no longer connected with this Station, has fully authorized the writer to present his part of the work. In view of the pioneer work of Mr. Slade his name is published on the title page as one of the joint authors. The writer is, however, responsible for the form of presentation of all of Part II. It should be added, also, that part of the work here given is due to the labor of Dr. Peters and is presented in the chemical part for the sake of convenience.
•Abstract in Biedermann's Centralblatt f. Agrikultur-Chemie, Bd. M, 1886, p. 473.
'Farmers' Bulletin No. 50.
•N«br. Exp. SUUoa Bulletin No. 18, p. 75.

6 J • 6 J
iat the amount of nitrate in Nebraska fields was too small o produce fatal results. This writer suggests that the plant nder certain conditions develops a highly poisonous chemial compound. Slade* in the Annual Report of the Station or the present year put forward the theory that such a com- K)und might be produced by the action of an enzym upon a ucoside found in the plant through a process of abnormal growth. On June 27 of the present year the Chemical News ' London contained an article on Cyanogenesis in -Plants >y Dunstan and Henry. This article, which fully confirms lade's prediction, was not known to Mr. Slade or to the riter till October 10. In brief, the England Chemists isoated from Egyptian Sorghum vuJgare a glucoside capable ! liberating prussic acid. In the meantime Mr. Slade had etected prussic acid in fatal sorghum grown in western Nebraska, determined the per cent, and secured strong evience in favor of the glucoside theory.
I On July 26, Mr. William J. Smith, of Cambridge, Nebr., I sorghum to a herd of cattle with the result that two died, le sample, received by Mr. Slade on the fourth day after tting, was weighed, ground up in a vegetable cutter, mixed th water, and distilled as long as prussic acid was evolved, le prussic acid found in the distillate amounted to .014 r cent of the weight of the sorghum taken. As later re- Its show that most of the acid is in the leaves, it is proble that the entire stalk here submitted to analysis conined a lower per cent of prussic acid than the part which e animal actually consumed. At this per cent, seven or fht pounds of sorghum might cause death.
[During the first two weeks in September, the writer disrered that prussic acid could be obtained from leaves of althy sorghum in the fields about the Station. As the st season was abnormally wet, nearly all of the fields had ide a vigorous growth. By distilling water from a suffisnt quantity of leaves, determinable amounts of prussic id were evolved in all cases, though the amount was well low the danger line. Of the common Nebraska forage mts, sorghum and Kafir corn alone yield prussic acid.
•A Study of the Enzyms of Green Sorghum, 15th Annual Report, Nebr. Exp. Station, 1902, p. 55.

I On the 7th of October the writer visited Colorado to instigate the outbreak of poisoning from Kafir corn described page 7 of this bulletin. By the courtesy of Dr. Head n, Chemist of the Colorado Station, leaves from the fatal Id were tested for prussic acid. The large amount obined was in keeping with the deadly character of the plant the field. Parts of the dried sample were found, on dialing, to yield as much as .1 per cent of prussic acid. At is rate, one pound might contain the fatal amount.
As both sorghum and Kafir corn are important forage plants, and as the investigations of the writer show that they contain as normal constituents compounds yielding prussic acid, the important question naturally arises, In what conditions of growth are these plants dangerous? The following have been suggested:
1. Young plants.
2. Second growth.
3. Frosted plants.
4. Stunted plants.
Unfortunately sufficient data have not been secured to enable the writer to give a final opinion on all of these points. They will, however, be discussed in the light of the facts at hand.
Young plants of vigorous growth contain a higher per cent of prussic acid than the bright, green leaves of plants reaching maturity. As the stalks and seeds contain no prussic acid, the young plants contain a much greater per cent of acid than the mature plants considered as a whole.
Second growth is not more deadly than first growth, although, as falls in the West are often bright and dry, conditions may be favorable for the elaboration of excessive amounts of poison during the second growth.
Frost is without influence except as the forerunner of a riod of bright, dry weather.
Growth arrested by dry weather before the plant begins to mature presents a condition very favorable for the elaboration of the poison. Growth stunted by too much water, sterile soil, shade of trees, or hardness of ground does not result in the formation of dangerous quantities of poison.
A study of the data at hand, field observations, and chem-

ical analyses, indicates that the poisoning is most deadly in Missouri, Nebraska, Kansas, and Colorado, and that it is rare east, north, and south of these states. The danger increases in Nebraska as one proceeds from the Missouri river westward. This cannot be attributed entirely to a dryer soil, as some irrigated fields have proven fatal. In general, however, we can say that the analyses of numerous samples show that dry, clear weather, T>y arresting the normal development of the plant, is the chief cause of the formation of abnormal quantities of poison.

The investigations made at this Station show that the >russic acid is not present as such, but that it is liberated rom a glucoside, (1) by an enzyin in the plant as in the ase of sorghum poisoning, and (2) by the action of boiling ater on the plant Glucosides of this sort are in themselves harmless and are dangerous only when they liberate >russic acid. Now the above table shows that even dried •lants may contain a very large amount of combined prussic cid. We should expect that such a fodder would be as fatal o stock after curing as when standing in the field. Experiuce, however, seems to prove the contrary. Enzynis rapidly become inactive when dried in the presence of proteid subances, as Mr. A. F. Woods, Chief of Division of Plant athology, informs the writer. In other words, the subtance capable of breaking up the glucoside into prussic acid nd other compounds is no longer active. This, now, is conirmed by the following experiment. 100 grains of Kafir orn were ground in the vegetable cutter; of this, one half as mixed with 200 cc of water and allowed to dry. The ther half was mixed with 200 cc of water extract of green sorghum leaves. After drying, this sample yielded on analys only one-half as much prussic acid as the sample that lad been treated with water only. This signifies that the nzym from the fresh leaves had liberated a considerable mount of acid. In this case the acid had escaped in the :mosphere; in cases of poisoning the enzym allows the poison to enter the system of the animal.
I Well-cured Kafir corn containing a large amount of prusz acid was fed to several animals. In no case could any mptoms of prussic acid poisoning be observed, although ie animal consumed material representing 1.2 grams of mbined prussic acid. One-third of this amount of free id is highly dangerous. In concluding this phase of the bject we do not wish to put ourselves on record as stating at plants become harmless on drying. We can, however, ate that there is at hand strong evidence pointing to such conclusion.
t There is a general opinion among stockmen that cattle ttening on corn may be allowed the range of fields of inted sorghum without danger of loss. During the sum-

mer of 1901 when instances of poisoning were very numerous, the writer watched for a number of days forty head of steers, on full feed of corn, that were allowed the range of a sorghum field that to all appearances was highly dangerous. No loss or symptoms of poisoning occurred. It is doubtful if in the presence of more palatable food stunted sorghum is consumed in any great quantity. At the same time there is no doubt that partially digested grain acts to a certain extent as an antidote for prussic acid.
The following series of experiments were carried out on a barren heifer in order to determine the effect of carbohydrates in lessening the poisonous action of prussic acid. Sufficient time was allowed between the experiments for the animal to reach a normal condition.
Result.
Prussic acid administered.
0.2 grams Slight symptoms
0 4 grams Animal very sick but recovered.
0.8 grains in 15 grams of glucose (se
[lected as a type of carbohydrate 6 grams in 30 grams of glucose. . .
Very slight symptoms.
Animal very sick, had severe convnl-
sions, but recovered.
ANTIDOTES.
I Prussic acid has a tendency to unite with certain carbohy¦ates, forming additional products. These compounds are uch less poisonous than the free acid. Both glucose and ilk sugar unite with prussic acid to some extent even in dite solutions. Aside from this action these carbohydrates tard the action of the enzym in liberating prussic acid, lese facts suggest that, in case the animal is not in such a ndition as to render medical treatment out of the question, e following may be effective:
I A strong solution of glucose, which nearly every farmer a at hand in the form of "corn syrup" or inolass<>s, may be ministered.
Large quantities of milk have in a number of instances been administered apparently with good effect.
I In all cases the animal should have as much fresh air as ssible.
